yl0lEwv0fzDHQLxML_Mh8w.text: Royal China, as a posh Chinese restaurant, certainly looks the part with dark panels for the walls, low lighting, glass topped walls between dining sections, gold-plated cutlery andwaiters/waitresses dressed to the nines. If only their food lived up to these expectations! For our meal, we started off with some wonton soup. The portion size was definitely not the biggest I've ever had and therefore I was expecting something special in the wonton itself. Well, though I wouldn't go so far as to say it was horrible, it was nothing special. We then moved on to our main course of Lobster Noodles (with ginger spring onion) with a side of bak choy in garlic. The Lobster Noodle is apparently one of Royal China's signature dishes so once again I was expecting something stunning. The lobster itself certainly looked good but was let down by the noodle and overall taste. The sweetness and succulence of the lobster was let down by the fairly bland ginger spring onion sauce. I could barely taste the ginger and the only time I could get the flavour was when I was chewing on the gigantic ginger pieces! The noodles also failed to absorb any of the juices of the dish and in fact I would even say that I felt the noodles cheapened the dish's overall appeal. I hate to give Royal China negative press as the only other time I've been in here was for the dim sum (which was pretty good if on the expensive side) but sadly it was a thumbs horizontal for me tonight.

i28e13DHTRjwxrYRXfnP1w.text: Several of my friends had been talking to me about this chinese restaurant and sugest that I should give it a try. Being an amateur of chinese cuisine, I finally decided to visit this place. Here is my verdict: their dim sum is THE best in town. It's incredibly fresh and tasty.Even if the staff is not very friendly (they're not bad but not the most welcoming people either), I'll definitely come back.

ce7HX3fZBctdShIUcV2Hnw.text: As the name suggests, this place is a little bit more classy then other Chinese restaurants on the Queensway.. it's 'Royal' claims are actually kind of backed up by the sleek interior decor - all black and gold... so pretty... The food itself is pretty good as well, serving some deliciously authentic Dim Sum dishes. The place has some excellent service as well, with the Waiters literally waiting on you hand and foot (the place was reasonably empty so they gave us alot of precedence) but, perhaps as a downside, the atmosphere is a little flat. It looks like you should be scared of dropping food or talking and laughing above a whisper (especially when empty!). A decent place, but not particularly my cup of tea. Look for some of the New Year offers and the Winter menu's they advertise on the front of the restaurant!

Z9tHhPZFAG66aJa6KabV3Q.text: No long review needed. Simply great dim sum. Get here around noon to beat the crowd!

cGG3wOYafrxUyvAwgsq1MQ.text: This was my favorite neighborhood dim sum place while living in London. It's a great place to stop for a quick lunch, which is what I did quite often on my way to work. You can order a few different types of dim sum (my favorite was the chueng fun with prawns), a pot of tea, and they even have dessert dim sum (if I remember right what I had was a poppy seed filled dumpling rolled in peanuts and served warm). And it's only a block away from Hyde Park, so when you're done eating, you can walk it off with a stroll around Serpentine Lake. Beautiful.

hj9Sy5m96IG7-wB_wrPlFQ.text: Authentic Chinese cuisine in London. I went here with a group of friends; and the four of us got a selection of dim sum plates to share, and found we couldn't manage the main courses as we were so full and satisfied after our starters. The food is well cooked and of a good quality and fresh, delivered to the tables promptly by friendly, polite and efficient staff. We had the classic items such as Sui Mai and crispy duck, which we had served shredded, with pancakes, cucumber, spring onions and plum/hoi sin sauce so we could make our own wraps, and the amazing steamed dumplings and cheung fun. Having been so impressed by this visit, I did return (on numerous occasions) and the main courses are just as impressive, with a good value for money. Again, I tend to go for classic dishes such as sweet and sour prawns with rice or roasted duck but I have never had a bad experience and it's the best restaurant on a street which has many Chinese establishments in close proximity.

HQdWaz2JvoemqtPeMMyDVA.text: Chicken satay was like rubber. Everything else way too salty. Not as good as i remembered (3 yrs ago).

NDtK4k-Yefck0gVFrZm0zw.text: Seriously yummy and affordable dim sum. A little hard to get a seat on a sunday but otherwise really worth the wait and their cheung fuen is really good too.

IKAQZmGE1-uIsMZCh4SJzQ.text: I have been lucky enough to have eaten Dim Sum at some of the best in Hong-Kong, and the quality of cooking here in the Royal China is comparable to the best there. The first time I ate here, just after getting back from Hong Kong, I was astonished, but after several visits, I now take it for granted. The service is polite and friendly. Also it very very cheap for what you pay for!

F8XzVo091HMNpnSifZJ7cg.text: Dim sum was faultless and as good as any you will find from California to NY to Hong Kong.   This is the real deal.   Prepared fresh.   Good variety.   We've taken many a visitor here for dim sum and always a success.      Our Parisian friends were very impressed with their dim sum lunch and still talk about it.   Elegant decor.    Excellent service.

yuidkYCAfEhkLqGs1W9kzQ.text: Simply the best dim sum place in London. The fried rice is amazing too!

psfT8i6m8zdlFzlQNGk38A.text: After walking through Hyde park on a drizzled afternoon, we were so pleased to find Royal China.   We ate dim sum, kept it simple. Shanghai dumplings and Shrimp and chive dumplings. they were the freshest dumplings I have ever tasted. Was so surprised to have tastier dim dum in London over SF.  Anthem we ate half a duck. Normally duck is too oily for me, not the case here. The duck was most without being oily, and not fatty.Thank you for the great experience!

B1BpiEPkqON_KoHS48q31w.text: With large neon lighting sign that read DIM SUM served daily.  We went here for a dinner, and was told dim sum was only during lunch.  FAIL.  However we ordered some ala carte dishes that were pretty tasty.  Soft shell crab with salt and seasoning was so good we had to order a 2nd order.  We also ordered the Lotus wrapped fried rice which was pretty tasty.  The order of the short ribs was also fall off the bone good.  I would have given a higher rating had it not been for the crappy attitude of our waitress and the fact they had deceiving advertisement.  The price was also on the high end especially for chinese food.  I probably would not return if I was in the area.

dXOcsniMWhoDXKLIhI3wYQ.text: Royal China @ Queensway(Pics at The London Foodie)I have been coming to Royal China (RC) for the last 12 years, and have nearly always enjoyed my dim sum there. My preferred branch is their flagship restaurant on Queensway, and the only place where I can have one of my most loved dim sum dishes "Baked Seafood Rice in Creamy Portuguese Sauce". Hakkasan is another favourite dim sum joint, however I find myself going less frequently to the West End as the years go by. Dim sum at Hakkasan is a completely different ball game (just as good but in a different way), and about 50% dearer.I went to Royal China last Sunday on 27th December 09 and was a bit surprised to find the place with no queue at 1pm. On the one hand, I was pleased that I would not have to wait for a table (RC does not take bookings for dim sum at weekends), but on the other, I felt that it lacked the crazy and vibrant atmosphere seen at the weekends. Staff were also rather uninterested, looking tired and sometimes being almost brusque. I was surprised to experience this considering RC charges 12.5% for service charges, and the level of service is usually good. Royal China's black and gold décor is surprisingly elegant. Despite the lack of windows, the Queensway branch does not feel oppressive but comfortable and roomy.The most successful dim sum dishes we ordered were:"Prawn & Chive Dumplings" @ £3.15 - these were as good as ever with the rice wrapper being silken and very delicate and the chives filling delicious."Pork and Radish Dumplings" @ £2.65 - I love white radish (daikon), and the addition of peanuts makes this one of my favourite dumplings."Glutinous Rice in Lotus Leaf" @ £3.50 - with a delicious filling of chicken and mushrooms, encased in sticky rice, and wrapped up in lotus leaves, this steamed dim sum is stodgy but well flavoured."Royal China Cheung Fun" @ £3.60 - I normally order the prawn version but as a friend wanted to try the beef cheung fun, we opted for this dish which contains one of each, prawn, beef and char siu pork. As usual, the cheung fun wrapper was delicate, silken and contrasted beautifully with the meaty fillings."Ho Fun Noodles with Pork and Enoki Mushrooms" @ £8 - I hardly ever have noodles with my dim sum, however I was glad that we order it. It was an excellent dish and accompanied our other dim sum choices well."Baked Seafood Rice with Creamy Portuguese Sauce" @ £9.60 - I haven't yet discovered what this yellow creamy sauce is made from but it is utterly scrumptious, to the point that I dream about it. Meaty scallops, prawns, squid and fish are mixed with egg fried rice and topped with the creamy Portuguese sauce. A "must" on any visits to RC Queensway.The less successful dim sum dishes we ordered were:"Prawn & Coriander Dumpling" @ £2.65 - the rice wrapper was unusually thick on this occasion and I struggled to taste any coriander in the dumpling. "Roast Pork Bun" @ £2.65 - I love this and, as with Cheung Fun and Seafood Rice, order them on every visit. This time, the dumplings had considerably shrunk in size and the char siu pork filling was rather ungenerous."Yam Paste & Pork Dumplings" @ £2.65 - I ordered this in error (I had meant to order the pan fried turnip paste with dried meats which is sensational) and unluckily they were rather greasy and nothing special."Fried Mixed Meat Dumpling" @ £2.65 - again this was slightly greasy and lacking in filling. I struggle to find anything positive to comment on this one."Roast Pork Puff" @ £2.65 - I normally enjoy these triangular beauties similar to Brazilian & Portuguese snacks, but unfortunately this was another disappointing choice as the puffs were served stone cold and tasted a bit tired.I normally come out of RC feeling really pleased with the food and overall experience. I have to admit that on this occasion, I was disappointed as some of the dishes were not as good as previously and the staff had a tired and unfriendly look about them. I still enjoyed the Baked Seafood Rice, the Cheung Fun and a couple of other steamed dumplings though so I hope that coming 2010, RC will pick up again and standards will go back to where they were.The total bill came to £74.40 including service and Chinese tea for 4 people @ £1.20 per person. At £18.60 per person I believe this is still a good value meal in London.Verdict - Variable quality dim sum and unfriendly staff made my latest visit to Royal China a disappointing one. Some star dishes and very reasonable prices warrant a "revisit" which I will report in the very near future.

e20fwoOK1MW4YQubcWm6xg.text: Overrated, but I can see how Europeans or Chinese students (with low expectations of Asian food in the West) away from home could like it.  To the Chinese students, I say, if you want to leave home, move to the West Coast of the States instead.Short dim sum menu, and the actual things on the dim sum menu are very very standard Cantonese stuff.  The most mediocre "Glutinous Rice in Lotus Leaf" I've had in my life. Egg tarts slightly too sweet.  Red oil dumplings (which are technically from Sichuan) had thick dumpling wrappings--were more like dumplings from Northern China rather from Sichuan (they're supposed to be thin and smooth, not thick and lumpy).  For London, this place is probably good.

jovNmplrnW8rsNsGlQCxDw.text: Good food and a very nice interior too! Great for a special occasion.The service was a bit slow though..

lew21-ETXD_AQlE2yuppqQ.text: It's always good at times to dine at a Chinese restaurant far away from all the relatively homogenised restaurants in China Town. Slap bang in Queensway, this is a really decent place to go for dim sum, especially for a nice sunny Sunday lunch (be sure to pre-book), in which afterwards you can walk it off in the picturesque Hyde Park. Settle down with a pot of Chinese tea (Jasmine is always a good choice), and order a few dim sum dishes such as the prawn and chive dumpling, roast pork buns (always a must), spare ribs in black bean sauce, if your daring the chicken feet in black bean sauce is good, but not for the squeamish. Be sure to order egg tarts as they make them really well here. Peking duck served with pancakes, spring onion, cucumber and hoisin sauce (oyster sauce) is popular, and made just right, where the meat is tender and the pancakes hot. I almost always order crispy fried noodles with beef and capsicum. There's just something about the deep fried grease of the noodles I just crave.Royal China has a real lively buzz to the place. Like many Chinese restaurants it's loud and there are always waiters rushing around here and there trying to fulfill everyones' needs.

photos.caption: Photo of Royal China - London, United Kingdom. Shrimp dumplings
Photo of Royal China - London, United Kingdom. Peking Duck
Photo of Royal China - London, United Kingdom

8CKdD1gukH3aIwl8W2J4nQ.text: I have been craving dim sum since I moved to London. In California, the dim sum places are usually a little shady when it comes to the cleanliness and service. But I was really surprised how nice this place was. Royal China doesn't have the traditional dim sum cart service, but the servers are pretty attentive when you want to order more. I was really surprised about how good this place was, it tasted just like the Chinese dim sum places in California! I suggest the morning glory dish (sautéed veggies in garlic), roast pork buns, and the spare ribs in black bean sauce. For two people, the bill came out to 40 quid. I guess it's pretty high, but that's probably because we're both pigs. Will come back again.

0A7BVrlltuEOGSYf9L9jaw.text: Royally AuthenticI've done a lot of dim sum in my day living in NYC and visiting HKG and Vancouver.  The Royal China ranks up with the best of them this side of the western hemisphere.  We ordered the shrimp cheung fun which were perfect.  The shumai and spicy chicken feet were equally good.  Make sure you ask for the specials - if you don't mind spending 10 quid on a plate of suckling pig, then go for it.  But save room for the noodles - the beef ho fun or seafood fried noodles are equally great to top off your meal.Pros: good for groups, kid friendlyCons: a bit pricey for chinese food, terrible wait after 12:00 on the weekends

EreqXbCU2lpHDPo7iVkw-w.text: Turns out London DOES have credible dim sum after all; you just have to stay the hell away from Chinatown to get it.The dim sum at Royal China was better than at most places I've been to in New York, surprisingly enough.  The dishes were not very greasy, and were very well presented - much prettier than I'm used to for dim sum.The one big flaw is that you have to order off the menu - no pushcarts.  That makes it not really dim sum in my mind.  But, then again, maybe that's why everything tasted a little fresher.

Dtkb9zzTLRQ0J6FVHV-GAQ.text: Good Chinese food and a better than normal setting. Was crowded a full locals thus not a tourist trap. We had hot and sour soup which was very tasty and the Singapore noodles both of which hit the spot for appetizers.  The black bean chicken was great and the portions were large. Many of the restaurants on Bayswater looked yummy.  I would go back and would take my family.

8pfrx7TcYrTrSiHMOns-yw.text: Decent dim sum at reasonable prices. My schoolmates and I went here on occasion to satisfy our Cantonese food cravings. Nice little dumplings and much more choices than I thought there would be...they even have chicken feet.

r61H1KXFhPjKGeyUClMO2Q.text: Royal China Queensway - Pics The London Foodie(thelondonfoodie.co.uk ) I have been coming to Royal China (RC) for the last 12 years, and have nearly always enjoyed my dim sum there. My preferred branch is their flagship restaurant on Queensway, and the only place where I can have one of my most loved dim sum dishes Baked Seafood Rice in Creamy Portuguese Sauce. Hakkasan is another favourite dim sum joint, however I find myself going less frequently to the West End as the years go by. Dim sum at Hakkasan is a completely different ball game (just as good but in a different way), and about 50% dearer. I went to Royal China last Sunday on 27th December 09 and was a bit surprised to find the place with no queue at 1pm. On the one hand, I was pleased that I would not have to wait for a table (RC does not take bookings for dim sum at weekends), but on the other, I felt that it lacked the crazy and vibrant atmosphere seen at the weekends. Staff were also rather uninterested, looking tired and sometimes being almost brusque. I was surprised to experience this considering RC charges 12.5% for service charges, and the level of service is usually good. Royal China's black and gold décor is surprisingly elegant. Despite the lack of windows, the Queensway branch does not feel oppressive but comfortable and roomy. The most successful dim sum dishes we ordered were: Prawn & Chive Dumplings @ £3.15  these were as good as ever with the rice wrapper being silken and very delicate and the chives filling delicious. Pork and Radish Dumplings @ £2.65  I love white radish (daikon), and the addition of peanuts makes this one of my favourite dumplings. Glutinous Rice in Lotus Leaf @ £3.50  with a delicious filling of chicken and mushrooms, encased in sticky rice, and wrapped up in lotus leaves, this steamed dim sum is stodgy but well flavoured. Royal China Cheung Fun @ £3.60  I normally order the prawn version but as a friend wanted to try the beef cheung fun, we opted for this dish which contains one of each, prawn, beef and char siu pork. As usual, the cheung fun wrapper was delicate, silken and contrasted beautifully with the meaty fillings. Ho Fun Noodles with Pork and Enoki Mushrooms @ £8  I hardly ever have noodles with my dim sum, however I was glad that we order it. It was an excellent dish and accompanied our other dim sum choices well. Baked Seafood Rice with Creamy Portuguese Sauce @ £9.60  I haven't yet discovered what this yellow creamy sauce is made from but it is utterly scrumptious, to the point that I dream about it. Meaty scallops, prawns, squid and fish are mixed with egg fried rice and topped with the creamy Portuguese sauce. A must on any visits to RC Queensway. The less successful dim sum dishes we ordered were: Prawn & Coriander Dumpling @ £2.65  the rice wrapper was unusually thick on this occasion and I struggled to taste any coriander in the dumpling. Roast Pork Bun @ £2.65  I love this and, as with Cheung Fun and Seafood Rice, order them on every visit. This time, the dumplings had considerably shrunk in size and the char siu pork filling was rather ungenerous. Yam Paste & Pork Dumplings @ £2.65  I ordered this in error (I had meant to order the pan fried turnip paste with dried meats which is sensational) and unluckily they were rather greasy and nothing special. Fried Mixed Meat Dumpling @ £2.65  again this was slightly greasy and lacking in filling. I struggle to find anything positive to comment on this one. Roast Pork Puff @ £2.65 - I normally enjoy these triangular beauties similar to Brazilian & Portuguese snacks, but unfortunately this was another disappointing choice as the puffs were served stone cold and tasted a bit tired. I normally come out of RC feeling really pleased with the food and overall experience. I have to admit that on this occasion, I was disappointed as some of the dishes were not as good as previously and the staff had a tired and unfriendly look about them. I still enjoyed the Baked Seafood Rice, the Cheung Fun and a couple of other steamed dumplings though so I hope that coming 2010, RC will pick up again and standards will go back to where they were. The total bill came to £74.40 including service and Chinese tea for 4 people @ £1.20 per person. At £18.60 per person I believe this is still a good value meal in London. Verdict  Variable quality dim sum and unfriendly staff made my latest visit to Royal China a disappointing one. Some star dishes and very reasonable prices warrant a revisit which I will report in the very near future.

dySvXwJsFf94PKnsBCVXEg.text: I have just had dinner at Royal China and advise it was without doubt the best Chinese meal I have ever had in London. The restaurant was quite busy but the meal was served quickly and was presented beautifully. I had a pleasant appetiser of steamed dumplings  which unfortunately had to much sauce but the main course of fried  fish fillet in corn sauce was outstanding. The light batter coating  with drizzled with a delightful sauce. Not cheap but well worth the money and a nice surprise for a suburban restaurant.

k6v2DizvttbT3hPaSbl0lw.text: Got a hankering for some good dim sum, tons of tea, or mango pudding?  Royal China is the perfect spot for you!My first time here, I enjoyed their entrees.  The meal pleased my tastebuds, but I'm not sure if it was b/c I was starved or if my friend who ordered picked the right dishes.  Either way, I knew I'd come back at some point.My next visit was for some dim sum with my girlfriends.  We ordered quite a bit, spending roughly £16 each, but everything was scrumptious.  From dumpling to pork buns to fried to dessert... omg, the entire 2+ hours we sat there, we devoured all the food set before us.  And I mean, DEVOURED.  And the pot of tea was bottomless, I swear.  Definitely come here for some quality dim sum.Note though - most of the staff come off as indifferent (or unfriendly).

jcGI2IbTAFldEv3WiIYm5w.text: I have visited this resto since 16 years ago when I was still in university. Visited again last week for dim sum, the dim sum still maintained its high quality and did not let us down. Their dim sum is so reputable that you can buy certain items frozen from selected chinese groceries place and enjoy them at home.

z6tci0vc8oN794T8Dxg2HQ.text: I have been to Royal China over a dozen times in the past 5 years and the place constantly delivers quality Chinese cuisine every time. The service is very good and the food is excellent. They are renowned for their dim sum on Sundays but do excellent crispy duck and noodles. Having been to Hong Kong and stuffed my face there - Royal China is as good. Great for big parties.

YiDdCbWAl5xIEwBRY5uEow.text: Recommended by a local. Food was well above average but, unfortunately, so was the price. Still we had a food time and a good meal. I would return except Ohio, USA is a little far away!

UphRS4wvfzZ4yD7GYQBLew.text: The Royal China in Queensway reliably serves the finest examples of Dim Sum in town. I have tried their other branches in Baker street and Canary wharf, though this branch is the original and best in my humble opinion. Service is consistently the most efficient I've seen, which I enjoy though others might feel a little rushed. It's best to get introduced by a friend to wonderful world of Dim Sum aka Yum Cha.

rOYVm5cgw7_JZ_0WplHv7A.text: I'd say this place is a pretty authentic Chinese restaurant in an area of Queensway where there are plenty of Chinese shops and lots of the local population are Chinese. The restaurant itself actually reminds me of something you might see back in the big country, it's all lacquered black paint, mirrors, gold leaf and minimal designs of typical scenes.We went last on a Sunday evening and when we arrived at 9pm we had to order pretty quickly as they were closing soon. We ordered some classics like Cantonese duck and barbequed pork which were really good quality as well as some tofu and beef dishes - also very nice. I have to say the staff were a bit brusque and didn't really help too much when we asked whether a whole duck would be enough for 5. Apparently she couldn't say as she didn't know how much we would eat. I can't help thinking this is only a fair comment if you have only ever seen other people get their nutritional intake via an intravenous drip in the mainline and have no conception roughly of what average size portions look like to average size people. Coming from a waitress with no obvious needle in her arm or bag of liquid vitamins behind her this seems unlikely. Having gone through all that though, I'd still go back. The food is really very good.

tV1vs5O9VbNTTbepcVxhKA.text: You could call this the baby sister of Royal China Club: It's cheaper and the food (and decor) is certainly less impressive. But I can assure you that the dim sum here is still a step up from what you'll get at some Chinatown restaurants. For around 12-15 pounds per person, you can get a filling meal of pure dim sum. Normally, I'd get the prawn har gau and shiu mai. When I go with my friends, I tend to be there at 10.30 am for no reason, and I will always see that there are people there already waiting for it to open at 11am. But good food deserves this.

sByDjclTgWA2Dw744fjBfg.text: Delicious Chinese food in a grande dining room. I go here for both dim sum on the weekends and dinner during the weekday - both are great.  I know there are a lot of other Chinese options on Queensway but this is the place to go if you don't want a "hole in the wall" dining experience. Service is fast and we've never felt rushed.  Long queues on the weekend for their popular dim sum.

wkl7E4owuVdGT1l8M1K1GA.text: A Macanese friend once tried to educate me about what makes great dim sum after i complained that people always complain about it not being good enough. According to her the entire restaurant/experience can be judged on the Xia Jiao (steamed shrimp dumplings)1) The skin of the dumpling must be thin enough that one can observe the little red veins of the shrimp through it.2) The skin must be thick enough that it does not break when lifted by chop sticks.3) The skin can not stick to your teethRoyal China passed on all three counts, and the other dishes were pretty good too

UyiHrOmLrmob81_BBfo2pA.text: I was taken there by my Chinese friends and it was one of the best Dim Sum I have had in London especially all prawn Dim Sum e.g. cheung fuan and prawn dumplings are amazing!! I will definitely come back!!

eCz46603Ft5sbUTm_2RhQQ.text: Well presentedMiniture food!Every thing with pork tasted superb! (roast pork dumbling, pork with crispy pastry yum yum)Dersert was glorious (mango heart shaped dersert plus egg custurd tart.)Customer service was indifferent!If you are looking for a serious heavy duty munch, Dim Sum is not the one. If you are looking for a light delicious meal to tantilize your taste buds thats not heavy duty, Dim Sum is the one.

photos.caption: Photo of Royal China - London, United Kingdom. Mango chilled dersert!

G4eJnKrLXVTOkadSBtZb6g.text: What fun at Royal China on Sunday dim sum day.  The place was bursting at the seems when we arrives.  I was in the mood for dim sum so I tried prawn dumpling gorgeous, roast pork bun.  The prawn cheng fun was delicious.  Filled up with the rice in leaves.  A bit expensive for what you get so if you are looking for value for money this is not the place for you.  However, the food is good and authentic and the waiter gave us a pot of water for us to use our own tea bay so that was good.  The service was fast and the food came quickly so I was happy about that.  We had to ask for chlli sauce 4 times but I forgive them.  I recommend this restuarant.

UrbAHr_31czPs9MUI0toQQ.text: My first real dim sum in London and this place was A O K. I mean I didn't DIE but it wasn't anything spectacular. When it comes to dim sum, I don't really care about the service or the presentation or the decor or the ambiance. I guess it was a plus that we got our own table and didn't have to share but I am just here for the food and the food here was meh compared to most banquet-hall-pushcart-factory establishments in NYC or LA or SF. Ha gow needs more shrimp differentiation and glutinous wrapping. Cheung feng needs more feng. I will say that the chicken feet were maarrrrvelous. There is also no gai lan on the menu but it exists if you ask for it. Everything was missing its usual dipping sauce but maybe this is just a different choice in presentation?There are no reservations for weekend dim sum but the turn over is pretty quick so you will likely not have to wait more than 30 min. I guess I would return but wait are you serious, this is the most highly rated dim sum place in London?

PZcjLgaijMTuKOe4zUpaYA.text: If you're craving some American-style-greased-up-and-fried Chinese food, this will most definitely satisfy your craving.  The food came within 10 minutes of ordering, which was GREAT. I recommend the shredded chicken fried noodles, and if you get the roasted duck they dangled in front of the window, make sure to put lots of the sauce (on the plate) on it!

5O9nWZwFptthTIxJTzc7Ag.text: Better than the rest. For the reasonable price, the food here is remarkably head and shoulders above other Dim Sum places in the area. Gets busy on Sunday with lines out the door. Must be telling you something.

photos.caption: Photo of Royal China - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Royal China - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Royal China - London, United Kingdom

a0AATiRvfekiFlMrYZyZqw.text: I met up with my best friends from uni for dinner here last night.Royal China is a chain of Chinese restaurants across London. They have a good reputation, especially for dim sum.Arriving at the restaurant, the black decor with gold leaf detail immediately marks it out as a Royal China establishment. it was busy and we were seated towards the rear of the big dining room.One of friends had a train to catch and with a busy dining room, I was little worried as to how fast the food would come out. Well, there was no need - we had ordered quite a variety of dishes and they all arrived within 15 minutes.A whole steamed seabass had sweet flesh enhanced by soy sauce and liberal sprinkling of coriander and ginger over the top. Golden crispy fried chicken had moist tender flesh. Crispy shredded beef produced shards of delightfully crispy beef in a tangy and sweet sauce. My friend Tom ordered the unexpected hit of the evening - aubergine stuffed with pork in black bean sauce.The service was fast, efficient and attentive. Have a deserved 5 stars, Royal China!

OM0AjjoqrzUu7dGDzmbpGg.text: Excellent service, food was tasty and presentation a plus.  Quick service but not hurried.  Friendly and helpful staff.

bOLAHdwkkfsEZayv3ctQmg.text: This is the family go to place for dim sum. It's wonderful.Beef balls - great.Cheung fun - great.Congee - great.char siu sow - great.I think you get the idea. It's all good here, not had anything bad.It's fast and service is good (for a Chinese establishment).

P6b0NtjLIrpkyQIfO9FkMw.text: I definitely miss dim sum back in California but this place gives me a quick fix. The shu mai was a bit disappointing but overall the food was decent. We tried the bbq pork cheurng fun, don tats, and the pork dumplings. The cheurng fun had a generous amount of bbq pork and the noodles were soft and tender. The don tats came straight out of the oven with a perfectly flakey crust and creamy custard.

XFrJbVbfXe7ZsD0i4O0N5A.text: This place is famous for dim sum, but you can avoid long Sunday morning queues by visiting mid-week for dinner. The service is lightning-fast, and the food is delightful. Try the shredded smoked spicy chicken, the Chinese broccoli with two kinds of ginger, and, well, just about anything else. The flavours are clean and distinct, with no greasiness to mask inferior ingredients. Everything is on point. And don't be fooled by the narrow storefront -- inside, the restaurant is quite deep and spacious, with an upscale atmosphere. There's a different menu, but there's no wait and the food is just as delicious. Also, it's friendly to vegetarians: there's a prix fixe menu just for them. (You have to order in groups of two, but if you and your companion can agree, then why not try it?) There's also a prix fixe Peking-style duck dinner, for those who need a duck fix.

cJmmLYKk_NbuzrRSCrBBZg.text: A classic but well-executed dim sum menu. They give you a number and that puts you in the queue and it moves quickly.  Some of our favorites included the prawn har gao (not too skimpy on the prawns), the taro duck fritters (light and crispy and not too oily) and the steamed BBQ pork buns. Be aware that this is a white tablecloth restaurant and it is reflected in the service and the prices. Worth a try if you're near Hyde Park.

jmj0EzUAaPrt1A-ye6h-zg.text: Very good, authentic Chinese food.  What could beat having Chinese food in London?  The family (wife, daughter 18, son 16) was staying in Bayswater and we didn't want to walk too far for good food.  Peking duck was very good and just as good as I've had in Hong Kong and Shanghai.  I know that many Americans will shy away from having chinese food in London, but to us, good food is good food.  And, this was good food.

kmU38xFDnR4Tm5GezF3ftA.text: The restaurant offers a full range of dim sum - so great for selection.  The menu is quite authentic - although it is not quite hitting the mark in my view.  The dumpling skins could be quite doughy and some o the seafood / meat is not exactly the high quality ingredients....  waitresses are not the most helpful and friendliest either.  I prefer Pearl Liang in Paddington far better but if it is not a bad alternative if you happen to be in the area dn craving for Dim Sum - they also have a full dinner menu so great Cantonese option

FkOY0hJKjpOy2nl_ibggBw.text: Dim Sum has always kind of scared me, because you never know what anything is, and there's always the possibility of accidentally eating something horrible.At Royal China, that's not the case. The dishes are printed on easily understood menus (with pictures! yay!) and contain something for everyone, even the very tentative.I always see Chinese families dining here when I come, which I take as a reliable indicator of Royal China's quality.

RE6tii240Pz_jFNrXH6Nlw.text: I have been to the Queensway 'Royal China' many times over many years.It is really the best Chinese restaurant in the area overall after trying most of the others.The Dim Sum is so well known for being among London's best I will not go on other than to say get here EARLY!The menu is large and varied so even fussy eaters should find something to their liking.It is nearly always busy but the staff do their best in an efficient but not necessarily friendly manner.If you are in the area and chinese is on your mind - 'Royal China' should be your first choice.HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!

EHRFOWzJ9q1lXj5aIQxTFA.text: This place has been here for years. The food is more or less exactly what you would expect from China Town. Again, nothing spectacular but also nothing disappointing.Recommended if you're nearby and looking for something Cantonese.

ejYLaOzP-6NI9E-MH83uEw.text: Review for dim sum only.In 1999, I came to London after spending two months in France. I was craving Chinese food "from back home" (read: dim sum and Cantonese cuisine).  I asked to be taken to the best dim sum restaurant in London and I ended up at Royal China on Queensway.  I remember the food as being very good and comparable to dim sum in San Francisco.Fast forward ten years.  I went to Royal China for lunch today. The dim sum here has held up very well.  I've had dim sum in several London Chinatown restaurants in the past ten years, but RC's quality is far superior.Pork dumplings in chili sauce, roast pork cheung fun (BBQ pork rice noodle rolls to San Franciscan dim sum eaters), beef dumplings (steamed beef meatballs to San Franciscans), crispy spring rolls, chicken feet and pork spareribs steamed rice, and a pot of pu-erh tea set me back £20.70 (including VAT and service).  Yes, you pay for the quality here.

photos.caption: Photo of Royal China - London, United Kingdom. Chicken Feet and Spareribs Steamed Rice
Photo of Royal China - London, United Kingdom. Pork Dumplings in Chili Sauce and Roast Pork Cheung Fun

Y2s5ImtoFojIhfteETaYLA.text: I came here for dinner.I was craving for Chinese, so I didn't get a chance to enjoy it but it was fulfilling.We were asked many times to alter our dishes because they didn't have certain ingredients.Complimentary radish and peanuts - the radish was so salty and sour.Viet Spring rolls - 2? Seriously??Seafood Cripsy Chao Mein - no one can mess this dish up.Vegetables and meat.Lobster - they actually help you pick out the meat from the shell - I was happy about it.At least they acknowledged the empty teapot after I asked 2 waiters.

photos.caption: Photo of Royal China - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Royal China - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Royal China - London, United Kingdom

O4Y2Ms2ZxokHQCuZ6pU8aA.text: As a Chinese-American expat that recently moved to the UK, I was pleased that Royal China Queensway had most of the Dim Sum staples that I was accustomed to from the US west coast, but also that their service was very fast/efficient, and the food came out fresh from the kitchen (it didn't seem like it was sitting under a warming lamp).I agree with some of the reviewers that the prices were a little more expensive than what I'm used to in the US, but most of the Chinese food in central London / Zone 1 has also been this way.Royal China is probably on my short list of Chinese restaurants in Zone 1. They exemplify the Chinese efficiency, and I find their attempt at being "upscale" charming - similar to other Asian restaurants that use decorations that Western places would consider probably slightly tacky :)

vrAcirjo-ivsD9PtDUx7Qw.text: I am not amazed by this place. Food is rather expensive for what it is. Small portions and expensive mediocre Chinese food. I would not visit this place again.

photos.caption: Photo of Royal China - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Royal China - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Royal China - London, United Kingdom

7Gn53EdDZOKAMl-0cByG5A.text: Rolled out of bed hungover on a Sunday, and some friends and I decided dim sum was the cure! Having been my first time here, the 1-1.5 hour queue was a bit of a surprise (I'm unfortunately not a Londoner, who may have had this knowledge prior!) but like any city... Sunday's get slammed for brunch/lunch hours. Seems everyone was here on that Sunday! No big deal, we chatted outside for a bit. The food was very good! Being so busy, a few things were incorrectly served but immediately remedied. This staff seems more than capable of these very large crowds! Kudos to them. Overall, I'd give the food a 8/10. I'd likely return! Prices weren't bad and the quality was definitely there.

EXSIuQJLMobihZfK_DDtVw.text: DO NOT USE YOUR CREDIT CARD HERE! Or if you do, do not let your card out of your sight. After our meal, my husband took our toddler back to the hotel while I stayed behind to pay the bill. It was the only time I used my credit card the entire trip. When I paid, the server took my credit card away from the table, and I remember thinking, "Hmm, they don't do that in Canada any more." But then I put it out of my mind. Until today, two weeks later, when I went to pay my credit card bill online and saw several fraudulent charges. A quick phone call to my bank confirmed that they had put a hold on my account because of multiple strange purchases or attempted ones.I know that it had to have been the server at Royal China who took my credit card information since it was the only time in the past six months when the card was out of my sight. The food was excellent. And the service was fine (except for the whole theft and fraud thing). So go for a nice meal. But don't pay with a credit card. Or if you must, go with the server to the credit card machine.

YfL6XlgDmvso6BioYkGsJA.text: Visiting from the States. Prices are REALLY high compared to the states. Flavor a are decent and service is good. Appreciate that staff speak Mandarin, Cantonese and English well. Sorry for 3 stars but the value and price don't match up.

A1ox1JkvAakrA43He326bA.text: Royal China has been a reliable destination for Dim Sum for a long time and this original restaurant in Bayswater offers better quality than their branch on Baker Street. We arrived there just after 2pm and joined the long queue.Our visit yesterday did not start well.  Within a minute after our order, Prawn Cheung Fun and Fried Squid Paste arrived and they were just warm.  Cheung Fun was below standard to begin with - nothing special at all and lacked flavour/texture.  We could taste the fresh squid in the latter, but they really should have hot in temperature.  The rest of our order arrived piping hot, thank God!  Prawn Dumpling, Roast Pork Bun, Glutonous Rice in Lotus Leaves were all packed with flavour and we could taste the fresh ingredients throughout.  They were just flawless.The service was well organised in a way - as soon as the diners left, someone cleared the table,  someone else set the table and person in charge of seating guided the new diners in.  The manager remembered us from the past (long time ago) and brought us a pot of hot water (we used to bring Rooibosch tea). However the other aspect of the service was very poor.  They were just like robots that were programmed to ignore our requests and I had to ask four different people to get Chilli Oil; the same lovely manager came to a rescue again.  To be honest, the prices are on the higher side and I am so used to the lovely Dim Sum you can get in San Francisco at a fraction of the price.  I juts don't understand why they are so expensive in this country.  Considering the portion, it is hard to fill up with less than 4 dishes per person.  They also add 13% service charge, so it can be an expensive snack rather than a meal.

vOUfoQV2S0Xc68Mf61M_0A.text: This place is a wonderfully greasy Chinese joint that has the menu of your hangover dreams and crispy duck for daaaaaays. I found the choices absolutely wonderful in that there were many, and we were able to sample some wonderful crab, melba tofu, three types of noodles and all sorts of ducks with pancakes, which we all know I love more than my family. Overall quite wonderful, though large, sterile looking and not very cozy.

-Ru5jeI-jaHN5tQWfOE14g.text: Classic dim sum, exactly what we're used to in the authentic places in metro DC, LA, NYC, SF and Silicon Valley just without the steam carts.  Ordering off a menu takes quite a bit of the fun out of it.  Maybe the tables are too close together. Nicer interior than most dim sum places. Quite fancy. Prompt service.  Efficient.  My husband speaks Cantonese which helps but everyone seemed content with their service.  Great tube access right next to Bayswater.

Q6Ui9m179Kh9wbKHJuRaVw.text: Some shit service and some shit food. All food took under 10 minutes to get to the table after ordering, and we ordered A Lot Of FOOD! Not fresh, although their rice dishes are decent. Waiters are terribly mannered, and extremely rude to customers. Terrible terrible terrible, especially for the price of the food.

jVZeq2_Rbu00SngX5AhOvQ.text: Came here with relatives last September 2013 during my first visit to London. I must say, what a surprise. Upon arrival, we were seated promptly, and the staff was friendly. There were 4 of us dining together and we ended up ordering a good amount of food.We ordered a variety of dishes...the food came out in a timely manner. I had a taste of the seafood soup, peking duck, pork buns, seafood fried noodles, and a variety of dim sum. It was all delicious!There were only a few other groups dining among us. The atmosphere was very relaxed and enjoyable. This was a great place to go with my family and travel buddy!

photos.caption: Photo of Royal China - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Royal China - London, United Kingdom. Seafood Soup
Photo of Royal China - London, United Kingdom. Outside

21vtOC_rRItHXw8iG4tB4Q.text: exceptional. We ordered 4 dishes and shared them at the table, each unique and dishes. The portions were a good size. the hot and sour soup was some of the best Id ever had,. I woudl go here again.

ic4exqevMg5epTBFN2YTAQ.text: Londoners don't know food. The fact that this place has good ratings proves that. Over salted crap is what they serve here. Good luck.

6E2G8_Jwm_Ri4TAq4sy7VQ.text: I have eaten at Royal China Restaurant twice now and I have to say that's it's some of the best Chinese food I've had anywhere. The first time I dined there was in Oct 2013. The most recent time was October 1, 2014.Three things strike you when you enter the restaurant. The first is the size. It's large by almost any standard, but particularly by London restaurant standards. The second thing is that the menu is large and diverse. Plenty to choose from no matter your dietary restrictions. The final thing is that the restaurant is full of Asian people eating there. That's got to be a good sign right? (That's not racist for me to say, is it? I would say the same thing about any sort of ethnic food where lots of people from that ethnicity were eating. Gosh, maybe that's racist too? It's too bad that people are so reserved on the Internet that I'll probably never know!)Anyway, back to the food. My most recent meal (shared with a co-worker) consisted of the following:Special Hor D'oeuvres Plate - Ordered by my dinner partner, we were both stunned by the side of this dish. It was huge. Definitely enough for 2-3 people. Most of the offerings were items that I don't or can't eat, but the reports I got was that everything was very good.Crispy Beef in Taro Nest - Absolutely delicious. I'm so happy when something is advertised as crispy and it actually is crispy. This beef dish tasted delicious and was fantastically crispy.Sweet and Sour Chicken - Very good. Perhaps not so different from Sweet and Sour Chicken I've had at other top-not restaurants. Like the Crispy Beef, the entire serving was demolished. Vegetables in Crispy Noodles - If I'm eating at a Chinese restaurant, guaranteed I'm eating this dish along with the others. The noodles were unique to me. Thin, short and crispy. I liked them. Fried Toffee Bananas - Let's see, bananas deep friend in batter and then drenched in a sweet toffee sauce? Um, yes please. In addition to these items I had two glasses of wine, and my co-worker had a diet coke and ice cream. The total bill came to (L)87.12 or about $144, including a 13% gratuity which was automatically added to the bill. Service was attentive and polite. The restaurant is attractive and clean. We both walked out full and happy. The same experience I had on my last trip to London a year ago.It's a bit of a conundrum, isn't it? I mean, London has tens of thousands of restaurants to explore. I'm there once or twice a year. It feels a bit like I should never eat at the same restaurant twice. But then again, when you're hungry and want a reliable meal that you know is also going to be delicious, why risk going somewhere new? At least that's the argument that won out this time. Ultimately, our experience did nothing to dissuade me from a three-peat visit on a future trip.

xNRtL6Q54_AkGE17AR-Xmw.text: Great place for dim sum in London near Baker Street.  I am not a dim sum expert but I certainly dined with quite a few who are. We all agreed that the selection and quality is outstanding. Service here is above average as well. This is a fun place to go with family and friends to share and try different food together. It's a popular place so I suggest getting there when it opens (especially on weekends).

yGjz1Ra4byXNTgVPI_qmhg.text: Quality and authentic Chinese. We've been going here for years. From experience, the food here is the best branch in London of all their locations. Be warned its busy for dim sum and there is always a wait but it's worth it.

DcHfDXadY19N-A992PRfZg.text: My uncle suggested dim sum for lunch and so we popped by. It was reasonably full, even at 12pm (opening time) on a weekday. Impressive, right? Uh, no. Royal China used to be our place for 'fancier' dim sum but the last few times I've been here it's been NYEHHHHH.The har gow, siu mai and lo mai gai were good but the cheong fun was mushy (clearly way too long in the steamer) & the cha siew sou was stodgy and not flakly at all! It was so bad all four of us cringed after biting into it :( (this genuinely saddens me because I honestly don't understand how an institution like Royal China could be so sub-standard).Although disappointing, that was all fine and well but when our guo tie arrived, everything fell apart. Not only was the skin thick and 'unfried' (only small spots on either side were browned / or should I say charred.. uh, what?) the meat was so pink! I'm fine having my pork rare-ish, but this I passed on.Reasonably, we sent it back, only for the waitress to pull the most sour face, drag two colleagues over and patronisingly insist it was fine! Yes yes, we may not be from Hong Kong or Southern China per se but we certainly are cantonese so don't treat us like idiots, saying 'this is how it's done' like we don't know what *real* dim sum is, or what cooked meat looks like for that matter. Unsurprisingly, its replacement wasn't any better but we ate it anyway because well, you gotta pick your battles! Life goes on..This was a real downer and after numerous average-to-bad experiences, I'm writing Royal China off for good. I acknowledge that some (most?) Chinese restaurants offer service with an attitude but you can't have that and meh food! IT'S THE UNWRITTEN RULE! Well, I guess they really don't care so long as they get your money zzzz.

p1BPjnPix2hVyWAhK5bl9A.text: This is a difficult review to write...You see, the dim sum at Royal China is excellent. You can go there and for a very reasonable price, come away feeling full of delicious food. The chefs are obviously good at what they do.The problem is the people who serve the food to you. If you hold a teapot in the air for 5 minutes (we timed it) you expect someone to at least acknowledge you in that time even on a busy Saturday. If you then turn on a strobe light on your mobile phone and wave it around for 2 minutes to attract attention while people at the surrounding tables all laugh, you expect some kind of acknowledgement.And when someone finally arrives, and you tell them you were waiting for so long, you don't expect them to say "well, we are busy!" in an angry tone of voice. You also then don't expect the manager to back them up without even so much as an apology for it.So to summarise, go here if you want tasty dim sum and have lots of time to kill waiting around for useless service. But if you have that much time to kill, get the tube to their Canary Wharf branch instead!

rd7DAYON31EX4v68fPpGtw.text: Excellent food and attentive waiting staff. Not horribly expensive either. Will definitely visit again!

TE5p5L0XQSJUzup1Jqdajw.text: Quick glance:+ authentic dim sum+ wide selection + large venueFull review:I didn't know there's decent dim sum in this part of London until a friend brought it to my attention! The dim sum was delicious and we also had fried noodles which was good and not too greasy. Price is decent, staff is friendly, although arriving early is highly suggested despite the large venue - it gets filled up quickly!

pscyMVpbnPknd0CbWKjOxQ.text: Every dim sum portion was perfectly sized for two people, and the textures, flavors, and experience of each dish was more amazing than the last. What a great place, with exceptional service staff.

pBMucpzr8OU5tw-LSgbmfg.text: Worst customer service ever, the lady in the till has the worst attitude and not respecting people, no matter the food is good or not, if you use this attitude to treat your customer I don't think you would have a successful business, have a good day :)

OAsTgP6iu1xamb5GU2C1Nw.text: Good restaurant with beautiful decor. It's not the best Chinese food in the area, walk a few metres towards queensway and you'll find better food, for much better prices. Good service. Be careful as it can be extremely busy during the weekend.

ANpgUZsD5Vs6U-dtsjipmA.text: Awesome! Greatest Chinese restaurant I have visited so far. Taste was really brilliant and profound I felt. In terms of service, I was forced to rush gradually as overall getting busier.

photos.caption: Photo of Royal China - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Royal China - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Royal China - London, United Kingdom

SBWmhG6qkdR1o_nqLhe37g.text: Excellent Chinese food and superb hospitality at a very reasonable price! The menu has great variety, with lots of pescatarian/vegetarian/vegan options. I ordered the Singapore rice noodles without pork, and it was excellent. No over-powering spices, and a nice texture and curry flavor. The rest of my party ordered the lemon chicken, crispy noodles with beef in black bean sauce, all of which were excellent. I would love to dine here again!

MoTTUJx36YAPqjLfaSCnjA.text: I was skeptical when looking at the reviews about this place. I'm glad I did not listen to them and followed my instincts. We ordered the Peking duck,sweet and sour pork and a prawn dish. All thr dishes were amazing. Definitely will be coming back before flying out.

MzcUid4-h7HAk33vkqZaaQ.text: Decor a little dated and empty at 6pm which made me a little nervous. Ordered Peking duck which was as good as I have ever had. Wait staff fine..not super attentive, but fine. I didn't  know till we were done eating- my sister told me the bathrooms were gross, so cleanliness is a factor. My impression- this is a great place for take away..

WfrDejId_Qxn0pxh4Bw_tA.text: Excellent service, delicious food! Had the most satisfying meal during my London stay at this restaurant.  The service was fantastic and the dim sum was very flavorful.  We tried a couple different Chinese restaurants in London but this one was by far the most authentic and tasty.

PvbCPeJZ6V9dwjvV8V9DsA.text: Love the dim sum here, it's a must-visit restaurant every time while I'm in London. Beef ball, shrimp shumai and fried tofu skin wrap are my favorite.

22n1uyF_3O8m6GC_jfMpZA.text: I love dim sum on a Sunday mid afternoon, it's one of the best experiences with family and friends. Royal China is simply the royale pain in the butt for the wait and the poor poor service. The wait staff are clearly too busy, angry and rude. If you want to receive your 15 percent recommended gratuity then some positive, pleasant and nice Service would help. I know Chinese restaurants in this range can get a bad rap for service, but really we shouldn't put up with it anymore.

_whU6tFrhnEf3j4cvUc_Qg.text: I don't know, this place was kind of "meh" for me.  It's known as a dim sum place and the pork dumplings I had were really good but they really feel down on the black bean beef.  It was barely passable, at least with the expectations I had.   It didn't help that the hostess was kind of a B.  Just the must dismissive welcome, it really put me off.

z0ZWFm_UiCZrXBRq2QrrTw.text: Solid dimsum place in west London. Went for lunch with some friends, and we ordered a combination of har gow, shu mai, chong fen, baos, a rice dish and a noodle dish. Everything was very very good -- for instance, I could tell that the prawns in all the dimsum were really fresh. Service was prompt as well. On average, things took no more than 10-15mins to be served. Ambience was clean and spacious, which I very much appreciated as I don't often like the crowded, less hygienic places in the name of "authenticity." Hence, a good place for any occasion. Would definitely go back!

0K4gczd7Iuzb9E87DlTlXQ.text: I've wanted to come here for ages, but it took me a long time to get around to it! They say the best Chinese cuisine in London is to be found outside of Chinatown, and Royal China is one of the biggest names in town. We arrived around 11:30 AM on a Sunday and found ourselves in a short queue, but the time estimate was 15-20 minutes and they were pretty accurate with that. We were seated at a round table in the middle of the enormous banquet style hall, and ordered of a menu with pictures (I suppose London real estate is too expensive to have the walkways needed to have dim sum on trolleys).We put in an order for 6 dishes, with all of my favorites, and they came out rather quickly. The food was very authentic and well executed. We ran into problems when we tried to add another dish, for which we followed up with the staff 4 separate times and it took over half an hour to come out. The operation seems pretty smooth, with lots of staff walking around with earpieces, though there never seemed to be a single person assigned to serve our table. I'd like to come back for dinner and try their other offerings, as I am sure they would also be very good.

VjQA6PJGDBpm1RI2H37MSw.text: Didn't do the dim sum, but dinner was great. Seated promptly, shared a few apps - spring rolls and spicy dumplings, very tasty. I loved the small dish of spicy cucumbers that was offered once seated. Our mains were enjoyed also. Would be fun with a bigger group to try more things, but three of us got a few items to share. Service overall was good; our waitress didn't have great English skills but ensured she checked when she wasn't sure of an answer. This will be on my return list next time I'm in the city.

lpCXdVo3y8rLsmXYdRkrNw.text: went here with some Chinese colleagues so I trust that this place is good! we had pork soup, Peking duck, eggplant, fried tofu and prawns, sticky rice and a very nice tea. It was more than enough for the four of us (and we were really hungry too!) Loved it!

photos.caption: Photo of Royal China - London, United Kingdom. dinner

chxpFzTsoGRzafc6FC-NgQ.text: Royal China is dim sum central. Craving dim sum, I found my way here, surrounded by bustling chinese waiters and waitresses, a packed dining room, a busy atmosphere and elegant black and gold decor.  The prawn dim sum, prawn cheung fun, and fried prawn dumplings with coriander were good. The scallop dim sum was just okay and the vegetarian one was not good.The black mushroom with braised noodles I ordered were pretty terrible and doused in a very unappetising sauce. The menu is very authentic but that meant for me that there were very limited choices of dim sum (I don't eat pork) because there wasn't any chicken or beef dim sum, only prawn or vegetarian. The service here is also very slow, as we asked for soy sauce for our dim sum, but none had arrived. We then tried to catch someone else's eye to ask for it, but that took ages as every waiter/waitress seemed intent on ignoring us. The food did arrive quickly though and piping hot. I had an okay time here, and even though our menu was more miss than hit, I might try coming back for the non-dim sum menu (other than those noodles) sometime.

photos.caption: Photo of Royal China - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Royal China - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Royal China - London, United Kingdom. Mushrooms with noodles

xKUwttpPWbKLWXzEKVv_9g.text: The chili chicken, chili prawns, and fried rice were very good.  The beef in bean sauce was okay.  Attentive service.

Imb_NWLLsIO0jCwQN-BEnA.text: Although I live in the Bay Area, where we have our fair share of dim sum places, I went here because a good friend had recommended this place, said it was better than SF or NY. Sadly I agree, London has the best dim sum, not San Francisco, I couldn't complain about one item, all were delicious and done just

EfXdfyHehmb-aWdlXqeGbg.text: By far, the best dim sum that I have had in London. They have a loyal following and it is well deserved. I am already looking forward to my next visit. Order some full dishes off the dinner menu as well.

z8LFip-UKm9h7hyY6gk4-A.text: Best lobster noodles. I came back in consecutive 2 days. Must eat in London!!! Also ordered the crispy duck which was good. I think it's as good as Gold Mine which is just across the street. And my favorite steamed rolls. Yummy!!

photos.caption: Photo of Royal China - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Royal China - London, United Kingdom
